I have spent a certain amount of time in the last few months in thinking about the form which a general Crder- in-Council for the Trucial Coast might take, and I had intended to discuss the matter with you on your recent visit to Bahrain. I understood from Galloway however that you saw no particular cause to pursue this matter at the moment and I therefore let it rest. Now that the question has been raised again by the India Office I would like to submit the following views to you. 3. Obviously the question whether we approach the Shaikhs for cession of jurisdiction depends on the further question whether we have any effective object in view; or in other words whether there are to be considerable numbers of British subjects or non-Moslem foreigners imported into the Trucial Coast Shaikhdoms by P.C.L., over whom we should want to exer cise jurisdiction. So long as P.C.L. merely send in small parties of geologists for surface exploration (aided by survey from the air) it is clearly unnecessary even to consider the question. If and when the Company proceed to geophysical exploration on a large scale, however, then it is just conceivable/- The Honourable Lieutenant-Colonel Sir Trenchard Fowle,-K.C.I.E., C.B.E., Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bushire. U S-2- ccnceivable 'that, soins object may be served by our securing jurisdiction and having an Order-in-Council. But even then uiie Order-:n-Council must be of general application throughout all the Shaikhdoms (since such exploration will not be bounded by political divisions of territory) and it must be framed with strict regard to the realities of the situation. To be brief, there is no use in our applying an Order-in-Council of 80 or 90 sections most of which we are in no position to operate. We should require merely a temporary form of Order- in-Council and the draft that I have in mind is briefer even than that submitted by Howes with his confidential letter Wo. C/545 dated the 24th August 1938. 4. It seems to me that the first essential is to discover what P.C.L. are going to do in the next year or two and — roughly — where they are going to do it. Little object will be served by obtaining cession of Jurisdiction along the Coast alone if the P.C.L. parties are themselves operating solely in the hinterland. For a Shaikh to be in a position to cede Jurisdiction to us over foreigners he must presumably possess both de Jure and de facto Jurisdiction himself; and if for instance we were concerned with a large party at work in and around Jebel Faiyah should we have served any purpose by obtaining a cession of Jurisdiction from the Shaikh of Sharjah who, whatever his de Jure claims may be or may have been, cannot exercise de facto sovereignty in that area ? Similarly who is going to cede Jurisdiction to us over the area south of Baraimi ? These, after all, are the two areas in which P.C.L. display most interest at the moment. 5. mods.abstract: This file contains correspondence relating to jurisdiction in the Trucial Shaikhdoms. The main correspondents are the India Office, Foreign Office, Political Resident Persian Gulf; Political Agent, Bahrain.The correspondence discusses the creation of new Orders-in-Council for the Trucial Coast and whether this is needed before Petroleum Concessions progresses its oil discoveries. The file contains the Draft Trucial Coast Order in Council. Letters discuss whether war-time contingencies require new legal measures to deal with hostile persons. Also discussed are measures to contain the possibility of post-war attempts at penetration by foreigners including the American oil company and how to reply to a letter from the American Embassy. The file also includes letters from Shaikh Sultan bin Salim, ruler of Ras al Khaimah and Shaikh Shakbut bin Sultan bin Zayid, ruler of Abu Dhabi. There is a printed report of the External Affairs Department Trucial States Order-in-Council 1946.
